	> However, if A is a subclass of B then I would like a quick way to say
	> that if B fails then don't run those tests in A that require a working B,
	> but still run other tests against A that don't make direct calls to B. It
would
	> simply make the error tracing a bit easier and avoid running tests that I
	> know are going to fail.

>	Have you run into this problem very regularly so far? And if you have, how
>	big was the effort to sort out the real problem? My guess is that going
all
>	the way to define dependencies for every subclass relation is not
worthwhile;
>	at least not for me.

This is an interesting question. What I was proposing was an optional
ability on a given testcase, and I'd make the determination on a case by
case basis. I agree, I don't want to do this for everything all the time
(another reason I don't like the idea of using suites for it) -- most of the
time random order is fine -- but occasionally I'd like to do so.

I guess over the years w/ thousands of tests & thousands and test runs, I've
done it enough to want to consider this. If it were there I know I'd use it
significantly.

regards

Adam
